history.content:
I took 127 having taken Math54 and ee16a (when both are required to graduate a few semesters ago)

The one thing 54 is missing is SVD. So if u are motivated enough to self study that part, it should be ok.

Ee16a and b actually cover all the Lin Alg in 54 plus svd.

Math 110 is not necessary.

Since nowadays 16a and 16b are reqs , I recommend doing this route, as u don't need to self study svd, and u get all the reqs out of the way.

luck.

=============================================================================================================

Math 54 actually does cover SVD (check Nadler's Fall 2017 Math 54 course outline).

The best path depends on your goals. Since you are an EECS major, 16A + 16B are required for graduation, and I would agree with ^ that taking those two would

cover all the required Lin. Alg. material to then take EECS 127. If you want to take more math-y upper-divs in the future, I would still recommend 16A + 16B, but

you may want to take Math 110 at some point to increase your mathematical maturity.

---

Math 54 in some semesters covers SVD. (Like many CS courses, the exact topics covered can vary between semesters and professors.) Without a rigorous analysis, my impression is that it doesn't do so in most versions of the class.

I took 127 having taken Math54 and ee16a (when both are required to graduate a few semesters ago)

The one thing 54 is missing is SVD. So if u are motivated enough to self study that part, it should be ok.

Ee16a and b actually cover all the Lin Alg in 54 plus svd.

Math 110 is not necessary.

Since nowadays 16a and 16b are reqs , I recommend doing this route, as u don't need to self study svd, and u get all the reqs out of the way.

luck.

children.subject:
When the class began discussion of SVD, I was so lost. And then everyone else who has taken 16B was like Yes I got this. However, if you spend a week reading the proof and doing svd exercises, it might be enough. 

Have not taken 189. But I read a few 189 notes and found many of the ML concepts very intuitive after 127. Some I thought was redundant even. 127 definitely helps.
Thanks so much! Did you feel at a disadvantage at all going in without 16B? Also, how did you feel about the course? I’m guessing u took it for 189. Was it helpful?

history.content:
Just take 16AB --- that is the recommended route.

Math 54 is only allowed in the L&S CS requirements because a small subset of students need to take that for various double major requirements. It is decidedly not the recommended path. 

Taking Math 110 after 16ab is a good idea for people who want to engage with the more abstract axiomatic perspective on the linear algebra that you learn in 16ab, which emphasize the conceptual intuitive and modeling dimensions. You don't need Math 54 for 110.

children.subject: Personally would recommend taking Math 110 eventually if you want to understand Jordan form, and learn linear algebra from a more abstract point of view, which helps if you want to study random matrix theory later on, which is actually pretty important if you are interested in the theory behind statistical learning

history.content:
1) 16A/B

2) Math 54, Math 110

Also, would Math 54 be enough?
history.subject: Best path to EECS 127?
